Good to see Aoki Kanji is back after a while. And sparking yet another discussion about incest in the comments, nonetheless.

So basically, your reasonings are faulty and obviously comes from your aversion to social taboo. Did you know that in most early human cultures, incest wasn't much of a social taboo? This can be easily seen in their mythology, Greek , Egyptian, Chinese and Hindu... even the ancient sumerians. Many cultures were open to many things even homosexuality and bestiality. Christianity and its worldwide spread was a very major factor of a lot of things becoming a social taboo, particularly these 3. Homosexuality is generally accepted now tho.

Btw don't bring that bullshit about "birth defects" and "mutations" here. Those happen all the time regardless of whose child it is, these mutations are literally how evolution works. Recessive genes is another common attempt at this, it also happens all the time and it doesn't mean it's bad either. Blue eyes and red hair are examples of recessive genes. There is literally only 1 thing that's legitimate, genetic diversity. If you only have the same genes that get passed on, it's likely to have less protection against environmental influences because of the lack of immunity. Basically genetic reshuffling is less effective because there's less genetic diversity, different times and places require different survival characteristics and the same ones won't necessarily be effective the next. Higher genetic diversity give organisms higher survival range, tho it's almost never the most effective methods of survival. However again, lack of genetic diversity needs several generations.

Laws regarding incestuous relationships, even actual marriages worldwide actually isn't as constrained as people normally think.  The social aspect is 100% the major factor that people think that way, but for the most part the law doesn't care unless it's nonconsensual. Also that death penalty thing referred to homosexual incest in some muslim countries... which as you can see is largely because it's homosexual. I got curious while reading Bokutachi wa Hanshoku wo Yamete so I checked it out. lol

@krimpus_ The idiot with a wojak avatar doesn't get to talk down to anyone, especially when they're spouting flagrant lies. Every single one of the "risks" supposedly associated with incest (which you use to refer to inbreeding, despite them being completely different) has one-to-one correlation with accumulated mutational load, which actually derives from outbreeding. Outbreeding quickly accumulates mutational load, which is expressed in in any inbreeding following that unless/until the deleterious mutations are purged over time (which can also only occur through inbreeding). The numerous defects caused by miscegenation are more or a less a microcosm for the broader impacts of outbreeding as a whole. Inbreeding purges these deleterious recessives over time, lowers mutational load, reduces the cost of sex, expresses advantageous recessive phenotypes and reduces recombination load.

Whilst incest is reprehensible for many reasons its odd that congenital malformities are the main fear. For reference, the "Semipalatinsk Nuclear Test Site" is close enough to effect the nearby eponymous city. In an official report published: 11 births per 1000 (global average is about 4:1000) had observable malformity (Vakulchuk et al, IRME, 2014). In modern Japan, presuming these siblings have not had incestuous ancestry in the last 150 years there would be no transgenerational epigenetic retention (3 generation seperation) and an inbreeding coefficient of 25%, the probability of an inherited disorders by the likes of uniparental disomy remains unchanged but homozygosity has a significant increase. Thankfully populations like the American Amish and much of the Levant and Middle East act as longitudinal studies in inbreeding and its effects, so lets take Lebanon's: 5.5 per 1000. Not great not terrible. TL;DR Fuck your 1st cousin not your Sister its effectively harmless
